title: Iron-on t-shirt typeface
content:
I know this is obvious to someone... probably everyone on here but me.  
When you see it you also think of dirty industrialization.  
It's the type on their shirts...  
Thank You!!!

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [breaking-away.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150321232635/http:/typophile.com/files/breaking-away_0.jpg) | 22.63 KB |
| [325547528\_4c49a67b7b\_m.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150321232635/http:/typophile.com/files/325547528_4c49a67b7b_m.jpg) | 9.66 KB |
author: Taylor Sizemore

comments.content:
edit ... sorry, I was looking at the Breaking Away font, which looks like Princeton filled in.

You want the shirt ... oops.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150321232635im_/http:/typophile.com/files/cutters-tee_6222.jpg)

i remember some standard iron-on fonts from back in the day.

here's a bigger view. Is this what you're looking for?

can't quite identify it as a font, though. :(

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150321232635im_/http:/typophile.com/files/MRS_LEWIS_SINCE_3997.jpg)

I don't believe this exists in digital form. There's always [ITC Machine](http://web.archive.org/web/20150321232635/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/paratype/itc_machine_book_ot/?sample_text=CUTTERS&sample_size=74&acs_ss=-1&acs_p=1&acs_pt=24&acs=1), but that's a bit too condensed and many letters don't match. Another option is [FF Oxide](http://web.archive.org/web/20150321232635/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/fontfont/ff_oxide_solid_ot_bold/).

Jeff Levine's [Sporting Life](http://web.archive.org/web/20150321232635/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/sporting-life/?refby=typographica) and Canada Type's [Player](http://web.archive.org/web/20150321232635/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/player/?refby=typographica) are slabbed versions of this jersey lettering.

There is also [Superstar](http://web.archive.org/web/20150321232635/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/superstar/), but that has a thin outline.

- Mike Yanega

United, from House Industries, would be my choice. Lots o' weights/widths to work with.

[http://www.houseind.com/index.php?page=showfont&id=531&subpage=un\_fonts\_...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150321232635/http:/www.houseind.com/index.php?page=showfont&id=531&subpage=un_fonts_sans "http://www.houseind.com/index.php?page=showfont&id=531&subpage=un\_fonts\_sans")
Why do I always forget United?

woah... that looks good.  
It's just a small project and don't think I can justify the purchase.  
If you are working on a project for someone do you just add it to the cost?

Every designer does this differently. Personally I do not pass along the cost of the license(s) to the client\* because I know I will be using it again in the future and consider it the cost of doing business as a graphic designer.

\*Unless it is something the client requests and is so heinous that I want nothing to do with it afterward. In that case I do charge the client and transfer the license to them upon completion. :^P
